DOCNAME: CASE OF OTHMAN (ABU QATADA) v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: No violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Article 3 - Expulsion) (Conditional) (Jordan);No violation of Article 3+13 - Prohibition of torture (Article 3 - Expulsion) (Article 13 - Effective remedy;Right to an effective remedy);No violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-1 - Deprivation of liberty) (Conditional) (Jordan);Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Criminal proceedings;Expulsion;Article 6-1 - Access to court;Fair hearing) (Conditional) (Jordan)
JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;Lech Garlicki;Ledi Bianku;Mihai Poalelungi;Nicolas Bratza;Vincent A. De Gaetano
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE near GPE , then administered as part of GPE . He arrived in GPE in DATE , having previously fled GPE and gone to GPE . He made a successful application for asylum , the basis of which was first , that he had been detained and tortured in DATE and DATE by the NORP authorities and second , that he had been detained and later placed under house arrest on CARDINAL further occasions . The applicant was recognised as a refugee on DATE and granted leave to remain until DATE . As is the normal practice , the Secretary of ORG did not give reasons for his decision for recognising the applicant as a refugee .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant applied for indefinite leave to remain in GPE . This application had not been determined before the applicant ’s arrest on DATE . On DATE he was taken into detention under the Anti - terrorism , Crime and Security Act DATE ( see A. and Others v. GPE [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § DATE , CARDINAL DATE ) . When that Act was repealed in DATE , the applicant was released on bail and then made subject to a control order under LAW DATE ( ibid . , § § CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) . On DATE , while his appeal against that control order was still pending , the Secretary of ORG served the applicant with a notice of intention to deport ( see section CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE , the applicant was convicted in absentia in GPE of conspiracy to cause explosions , in a trial known as the “ reform and challenge ” case . He was the twelfth of CARDINAL defendants .

CARDINAL . The case involved an allegation of a conspiracy to carry out bombings in GPE , which resulted in successful attacks on ORG and ORG in GPE in DATE . There were further convictions for offences of membership of a terrorist group , but these matters were the subject of a general amnesty . The applicant was sentenced to life imprisonment with hard labour at the conclusion of the trial .

CARDINAL . During the trial , CARDINAL witness , PERSON , confessed that he and not the defendants had been involved in the bombings . ORG hearing the case took the view that his confession was false , and demonstrably so , because of discrepancies between what he said about the nature of the explosives , for example , and other technical evidence . Mr PERSON was later executed for homicides for which he had been convicted in another trial .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant maintains that the evidence against him was predominantly based upon an incriminating statement from a co - defendant , PERSON ( also known as PERSON ) . In his confession to ORG Prosecutor , Mr PERSON alleged that the applicant had provided prior encouragement for the attacks . He was also said to have congratulated the group after the attacks .

CARDINAL . Mr PERSON , along with several other defendants , had complained during the proceedings before ORG that they had been tortured by ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) , which shares responsibility for maintaining internal security and monitoring security threats in GPE with ORG and the military . At DATE of interrogation during which they claimed to have been tortured , ORG took a statement from each defendant .

CARDINAL . At the trial there was evidence from lawyers and medical examiners and relatives of the defendants that there were visible signs of torture on the defendants . However , ORG concluded that the defendants could not prove torture .

CARDINAL . There were a number of appeals to ORG and remittals back to ORG , although , as the applicant had been convicted in absentia , no appeals were taken on his behalf . In the course of those appeals , the convictions were upheld on the basis that the relevant statements had been made to ORG . The confessions in those statements thus constituted sufficient evidence for conviction if the court accepted them and if ORG was satisfied with the confessions . ORG rejected the claim that ORG had to prove that the defendants had confessed to him of their own accord : ORG obligation to prove that a confession was obtained willingly only arose where the confession had not been obtained by him . The confessions in question were authentic and there was no evidence that they had been made under financial or moral coercion .

CARDINAL . ORG then considered the impact of the allegations that the confessions to ORG had resulted from coercion of the defendants and their families while they were in ORG detention . Such conduct during an investigation was against NORP law and rendered the perpetrators liable to punishment . However , even assuming that the GPE allegations were true , that would not nullify the confessions made to ORG unless it were proved that those confessions were the consequence of illegal coercion to force the defendants to confess to things which they had not done . The defendants had not shown that was the case .
CARDINAL . As a result of the applicant ’s conviction in this trial , the NORP authorities requested the applicant ’s extradition from GPE . In DATE , the request was withdrawn by GPE .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant was again tried in absentia in GPE , this time in a case known as the “ millennium conspiracy ” , which concerned a conspiracy to cause explosions at western and NORP targets in GPE to coincide with the DATE celebrations . The conspiracy was uncovered before the attacks could be carried out . The applicant was alleged to have provided money for a computer and encouragement through his writings , which had been found at the house of a co - defendant , Mr PERSON . The applicant maintains that the main evidence against him was the testimony of PERSON .

CARDINAL . Most of the defendants were convicted on most charges ; some were fully or partly acquitted . The applicant was convicted and sentenced to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment with hard labour . Other defendants , including GPE PERSON , were sentenced to death . On appeal certain of the defendants , including , it appears , PERSON , claimed to have been tortured during DATE of interrogation when they were denied access to lawyers . ORG rejected this ground of appeal , holding that the TIME of interrogation showed that each defendant had been told of his right to remain silent about the charges unless their lawyer was present . The applicant also states that ORG found that the alleged ill - treatment in ORG custody was irrelevant because ORG did not rely on the GPE confessions to the ORG but their confessions to ORG . PERSON remains under sentence of death .

CARDINAL . The findings of GPE ( ORG ) in respect of the evidence presented at each trial are set out at paragraph CARDINAL below . The further evidence which has become available since ORG ’s findings , and which has been submitted to ORG , is summarised as paragraphs CARDINAL–CARDINAL below .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE , ORG advised ORG that LAW precluded the deportation of terrorist suspects to GPE . In DATE , after a Government review of the possibility of removing such barriers to removal , ORG confirmed that its advice of DATE remained extant but that it was considering whether key countries would be willing and able to provide the appropriate assurances to guarantee that potential deportees would be treated in a manner consistent with GPE obligations . In DATE , the ORG Secretary agreed that seeking specific and credible assurances from foreign governments , in the form of memoranda of understanding , might be a way of enabling deportation from GPE .

CARDINAL . In DATE , ORG in GPE was instructed to raise the idea of a framework memorandum of understanding ( ORG ) with ORG . In DATE , after meetings between the Prime Minister of GPE and GPE , and between the Secretary of ORG for ORG and the NORP Foreign Minister , agreement was reached on the principle of an ORG .

CARDINAL . Further negotiations took place in DATE and an ORG was signed on DATE . That ORG set out a series of assurances of compliance with international human rights standards , which would be adhered to when someone was returned to CARDINAL ORG from the other ( see paragraph DATE below ) . DATE , a side letter from GPE , GPE , to ORG was signed , which recorded ORG ability to give assurances in individual cases that the death penalty would not be imposed . In respect of the applicant , further questions as to the conduct of any retrial he would face after deportation were also put to ORG and answered in DATE by LAW at ORG .

CARDINAL . NORP The ORG also made provision for any person returned under it to contact and have prompt and regular visits from a representative of an independent body nominated jointly by GPE and ORG . On DATE , FAC ( “ the FAC ” ) signed a monitoring agreement with ORG . On DATE , the terms of reference for the ORG were agreed ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE , that is , DATE after the ORG was signed , the Secretary of ORG served the applicant with the notice of intention to deport . The Secretary of ORG certified that the decision to deport the applicant was taken in the interests of national security . The applicant appealed to ORG against that decision arguing , inter alia , that it was incompatible with ORG , DATE , DATE and CARDINAL of the LAW . Relying on his previous asylum claim , he argued that his high profile would mean he would be of real interest to the NORP authorities . If returned , he would also face retrial for the offences for which he had been convicted in absentia . He would thus face lengthy pre - trial detention ( in breach of LAW and , if convicted , would face a long term of imprisonment . All these factors meant he was at real risk of torture , either pre - trial or after conviction , to obtain a confession from him or to obtain information for other reasons . He was also at risk of the death penalty or rendition to other countries , such as GPE . Relying on DATE , he alleged that his retrial would be flagrantly unfair : ORG , a military court , lacked independence from the executive and there was a real risk that evidence obtained by torture – either of him , his co - defendants or other prisoners – would be admitted against him .

CARDINAL . The applicant ’s appeal was dismissed by ORG on DATE . The appeal had been heard by ORG in CARDINAL parts : an “ open session ” , where the Secretary of ORG ’s case and evidence was presented in the presence of the applicant and his representatives , and a “ closed session ” where parts of the Secretary of ORG ’s case which could not be disclosed for security reasons were presented ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . ORG heard evidence in closed session relating to the process by which the ORG had been agreed , the extent to which it would mitigate the risk of torture and also evidence as to the national security threat the applicant was alleged to have posed to GPE ( “ closed material ” ) . In the closed sessions , the applicant and his representatives were excluded but his interests were represented by special advocates . ORG then delivered an “ open judgment ” , which is publicly available , and a “ closed judgment ” , which was given only to the Secretary of ORG and the special advocates .

CARDINAL . In reaching its decision as to whether the applicant ’s deportation was necessary in the interests of national security , ORG considered the Secretary of ORG ’s case to be “ well proved ” since the applicant was regarded by many terrorists as a spiritual adviser whose views legitimised acts of violence . However , ORG did not take into account either of the applicant ’s NORP convictions in absentia , which were originally advanced as part of the Government ’s case . The reason for this was that the Government had adopted what was described as a “ pragmatic approach ” in withdrawing reliance upon any evidence which it was alleged might have been obtained by torture on the grounds that it would require an investigation as to whether it was obtained by torture . This was done in accordance the ORG of Lords’ ruling in ORG and others ( no . CARDINAL ) to that effect ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . ORG then reviewed the evidence it had heard from various sources including a senior GPE diplomat , Mr PERSON , who gave evidence on the negotiation of the ORG , the monitoring agreement with ORG and on the risk faced by the applicant in GPE . On behalf of the applicant , it heard evidence on the NORP regime from CARDINAL academics . It also received evidence from an LANGUAGE speaking barrister , PERSON , who had travelled to GPE to conduct research on the previous CARDINAL trials including interviews with the defendants and their lawyers . Additionally , it considered evidence of ORG interest in the applicant and allegations that a NORP national had been the subject of extraordinary rendition from GPE to GPE .

CARDINAL . ORG found that this ORG ’s judgments in PERSON v. GPE , DATE , Reports of Judgments and Decisions DATE and PERSON and PERSON v. GPE [ ORG ] , ORG . CARDINAL and CARDINAL , ORG CARDINALI , showed that reliance could lawfully be placed on assurances ; but the weight to be given depended on the circumstances of each case . There was a difference between relying on an assurance which required a ORG to act in a way which would not accord with its normal law and an assurance which required a ORG to adhere to what its law required but which might not be fully or regularly observed in practice . Referring to a decision of ORG , Agiza v. GPE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , where the NORP authorities had expelled an NORP national after receiving assurances from GPE , ORG continued :

“ The case of Agiza stands as a clear warning of the dangers of simple reliance on a form of words and diplomatic monitoring . There were already warning signs which ought to have alerted the NORP authorities to the risks , including the role they had permitted to a foreign intelligence organisation . But we note what to us are the crucial differences : the strength , duration and depth of the bilateral relationship between the CARDINAL countries by comparison with any that has been pointed to between GPE and GPE ; the way in which the negotiations over the ORG have proceeded and the diplomatic assessment of their significance ; the particular circumstances of [ the present applicant ] and GPE ; the degree of risk at the various stages , in the absence of the ORG , particularly at the early stages of detention which is when the risk from torture by the ORG would normally be at its greatest and when the confirmed torture of Agiza in GPE appears to have occurred ; and the speed with which the monitors would be seeking and we believe obtaining access to the Appellant in DATE . The NORP felt that to seek to see Agiza would betray a want of confidence in the NORP , whereas there is no such feeling in either the GPE , the [ ORG or ORG . Quite the reverse applies . CARDINAL aspect of that case which also troubled the [ Committee Against Torture ] was that Agiza had been removed without final judicial determination of his case . That would not be the position here . ”

CARDINAL . In the present case , the political situation in GPE and the freedom , albeit limited , of non - governmental organisations , the press and ORG to express concerns would reduce the risks the applicant faced . In addition , the level of scrutiny PERSON had accepted under the ORG could not but show that it was willing to abide by its terms and spirit . Each country had a real interest in preventing breaches of the ORG : the diplomatic relationship between GPE and GPE was friendly and long - standing and of real value to GPE and it would have a real incentive to avoid being seen as having broken its word . Both countries had an interest in maintaining co - operation on counter - terrorism matters . GPE had a very real concern that it should be able to remove foreign nationals without breaching their rights under LAW , so failure in such a highly publicised case would be a major setback for that process . That concern would thus act as a further incentive to investigate any breaches of the ORG . While the ORG did not specify what steps would be taken in such an investigation , ORG accepted evidence from FAC that any failure of ORG to respond to diplomatic queries would lead to “ rapidly escalating diplomatic and Ministerial contacts and reactions ” .

CARDINAL . ORG accepted that there were some weaknesses in the ORG and monitoring provisions . Some protections , such as prompt access to a lawyer , recorded interviews , independent medical examinations and prohibition on undisclosed places of detention , were not explicitly present but , in reality , most of these aspects were covered . There was no guarantee that access to the applicant , as required by ORG terms of reference , would always be granted but any refusal would be brought to light quite quickly ; in DATE of detention , the ORG was expected to visit the applicant CARDINAL times a week . ORG also expected the ORG and ORG to react swiftly to any approach by GPE were a visit to be refused . It was “ disturbing ” that ORG on Torture had been refused access to a ORG facility in DATE , despite a prior arrangement that he would be permitted free access . However , on the evidence it had heard , ORG found that there was no real risk of ill - treatment of the applicant by the ORG . There was a weakness in the ORG “ relative inexperience and scale ” ; it would be undertaking a task which would be new to it ; and it did not have the expertise among its staff , as it had recognised . It was a fairly new body with limited resources and staff , although this could be overcome and ORG would bear the cost . It was the very fact of monitoring visits which was important and the absence of specialist expertise was not fatal to their value .

CARDINAL . ORG did not contest the general thrust of the available material in relation to GPE ’s human rights record and , in ORG ’s view , details of human rights violations in GPE remained relevant to the assessment of the risk faced by the applicant . The Government also took the position that it could not return the applicant to GPE , in conformity with its international obligations , in the absence of the particular measures contained in the ORG . Nevertheless , ORG found it important to consider the risks faced by the applicant by reference to the likely sequence of events if he were to be returned . It found that the ORG might not be necessary for each risk but rather reinforce the protection available .

CARDINAL . ORG accepted that , on return , the applicant would be taken into the custody of the ORG and retried on the CARDINAL charges for which he had been convicted in absentia . He would be accompanied by a representative of FAC to his place of detention and be medically examined . ORG also accepted that the ORG would interrogate the applicant with a view to obtaining a confession for use at trial and for more general intelligence purposes , though ORG found it to be speculative that ORG would interrogate the applicant about other offences in order to bring further charges against him ; there was no evidence of any other charges outstanding . ORG also accepted that GPE would seek to question the applicant and that this would take place soon after his arrival in GPE . However , there was no real risk that LAW would be breached before the conclusion of the retrial .

CARDINAL . There was a real risk of torture or ill - treatment of an “ ordinary NORP extremist ” in ORG detention before charge since such ill - treatment was widespread and longstanding and there was a climate of impunity and evasion of international monitoring in the ORG . However , the applicant would be protected by his high profile , by the ORG and the monitoring agreement , especially since FAC would be “ keen to prove its mettle ” and would itself be subject to the vigilance of other nongovernmental organisations . This would also prevent any real risk of the use by the ORG of tactics such as TIME refusals of access , claims that the applicant did not wish to see the monitors or moving him elsewhere without notification . Access by ORG would also prevent the applicant ’s incommunicado detention .

CARDINAL . NORP The ORG would also counteract the climate of impunity prevailing in the ORG and toleration of torture by its senior members . The ORG and the monitoring arrangements were supported at the highest levels in GPE – the King of GPE ’s political power and prestige were behind the MOU – so it was reasonable to assume that instructions on how to treat the applicant had been given to the ORG and it would be aware that any breaches would not go unpunished . Moreover , senior members of the ORG had participated in the ORG negotiations and therefore would know the consequences of any failure to comply . Even if abuses were normally the work of rogue officers , the specific and unusual position of the applicant and the effect of the ORG would lead to senior officers preventing ill - treatment in his case , even if they did so only out of self - interest .

CARDINAL . Questioning by GPE was not forbidden by the ORG and , to ORG , it was probable that ORG would be allowed to question the applicant directly with the ORG present . However , GPE would have made clear to GPE its interests in ensuring that the ORG was not breached . The NORP authorities and GPE would be careful to ensure that GPE did not “ overstep the mark ” . Assuming that the applicant remained in ORG custody and was not surrendered to GPE , there would be no real risk of ill - treatment at the pre - trial stage . It was also highly unlikely that the applicant would be placed in any secret ORG or ORG detention facility in GPE .

CARDINAL . The same factors applied to any questioning which might take place soon after the conviction or acquittal of the applicant . The ORG would continue to apply and it would be in the interests of both the NORP and the NORP to conduct any interrogation at the earliest opportunity rather than wait until after trial . The applicant ’s high profile was also found to be “ unlikely to diminish much for DATE ” .

CARDINAL . There was little likelihood of the NORP authorities bringing any subsequent charges which carried the death penalty or seeking the death penalty in respect of the charges for which the applicant was to be retried . Instead , if he were convicted , the applicant would face a lengthy period of imprisonment . There was a real risk of a life sentence in respect of the ORG and ORG conspiracy , although there was a greater prospect that it would be considerably less because of the way in which sentences on the other defendants appeared to have been reduced on appeal , to DATE . There was no real risk of a life sentence in the millennium conspiracy retrial . There was no rule that would prevent a higher sentence being imposed than the DATE sentence that had been imposed in absentia . However , the clear practice was against imposing higher sentences in retrials following initial convictions in absentia and there was no reason why a more unfavourable view would be taken of the applicant when he was present than when he was absent . The applicant would serve any sentence in an ordinary prison and not a ORG detention facility ; the sentence of hard labour did not connote any additional punishment . General conditions would not breach LAW and , although beatings sometimes occurred , there was no evidence that the applicant would be targeted as a political NORP prisoner . His status would again act to protect him .

CARDINAL . In respect of rendition , there were “ powerful incentives ” for the NORP and ORG not to allow this to happen , not least the real domestic political difficulties this would create for ORG and the unwillingness of GPE to destabilise the NORP regime . Any instances of alleged rendition from GPE had involved people of other nationalities or , in CARDINAL case , of a dual GPE / NORP national . It was also very unlikely that the applicant would be removed to a secret ORG facility in GPE since this would require the connivance of the NORP authorities contrary to the ORG . It was also unlikely that ORG would seek the extradition of the applicant from GPE when it had not sought his extradition from GPE and there would be political difficulties for GPE to accede to such a request .

CARDINAL . NORP In relation to the applicant ’s detention following his removal to GPE , ORG found that the time limits for notifying the legal authorities of an arrest ( TIME ) and for bringing formal charges ( DATE ) were regularly and lawfully extended by the courts at the request of the prosecutor , in stages of DATE to a maximum of DATE . It would therefore be compatible with NORP law for the applicant to be held in detention for DATE without being physically brought before a court before being charged . Such extensions were approved by a judicial authority , although not necessarily in the physical presence of the suspect .

CARDINAL . ORG noted that the ORG did not explicitly require that there be no extensions of time beyond the initial DATE detention but required that a returned person be brought promptly before a judge or other person authorised by law to determine the lawfulness of his detention . Though “ promptly ” was not defined in the ORG , ORG found that this part of the ORG would be carried out , particularly since this was one of the earliest points at which the ORG would be engaged , and that the applicant ’s first appearance before a judicial authority would be within TIME . It would not breach the ORG if the applicant were to be detained for a maximum of DATE , by means of judicially approved DATE extensions , or if he were absent when those later decisions were taken . However , in reality the total period of DATE was unlikely to be sought , even without the ORG , because the applicant faced a retrial and the case dossiers had already been through the trial and appeal process a number of times .
CARDINAL . It was common ground before ORG that the applicant ’s previous convictions would be set aside and he would face retrial before ORG on the same charges .

CARDINAL . In addition to his CARDINAL challenges to the retrial process ( the impartiality of ORG and the use of evidence obtained by torture ) the applicant also argued that he would be questioned in detention without the presence of a lawyer by the ORG , GPE officials or ORG . The latter had the power under Article CARDINAL ) of ORG to conduct an investigation in the absence of a lawyer “ whenever he [ deemed ] it necessary in order to reveal the truth ” . This decision was not subject to review , though ORG also noted that a confession before ORG was not admissible unless the individual had been warned that he need not answer questions without his lawyer present . ORG thought it unlikely that the applicant would have a lawyer present during questioning by the ORG or GPE officials but very likely he would have access to a lawyer for any appearance before a judge or ORG . In terms of pre - trial preparation by the defence , the period and facilities available would be less extensive than in GPE but nonetheless better than would normally be the case in GPE .

CARDINAL . With regard to the lack of independence and impartiality of ORG , ORG found that the court would consist of CARDINAL judges , CARDINAL of whom would be legally qualified military officers with no security of tenure . ORG would also be a military officer . Appeal would lie to ORG , a civilian court , though that court could not hear argument on any unfairness of the trial arising from the military composition of ORG .
CARDINAL . As to the potential use of evidence obtained by torture in the applicant ’s retrial , ORG found as follows :

“ CARDINAL . NORP The NORP legal system , by its terms , does not therefore permit the use of involuntary confession or incriminatory statements . There is a judicial examination of allegations of that nature before the evidence is admitted . Those allegations can themselves be tested by evidence . How far those allegations can be practicably tested is affected by certain features of the system . The burden of proof for excluding confessions made to the Prosecutor lies on the defendant . There is obvious difficulty in proving prior acts or threats by the ORG in the absence of systems for recording questioning , for ensuring the presence of lawyers during questioning , and independent prompt medical examinations . There is likely to be considerable reluctance on the part of the ORG to accept that confessions to the Prosecutor , a common source of evidence , are tainted by ill - treatment . ORG does not appear prepared to compel the appearance of ORG officials to testify about these allegations . There may be a sense that these allegations are made routinely , as a matter of defence strategy .

CARDINAL . There may well be a greater willingness to test the nature of confessions made only in the course of ORG questioning . There is some evidence that at least at ORG level , confessions alleged to have been obtained by torture have been excluded , ( though it is not clear whether those were made to the ORG or to the Prosecutor ) .

CARDINAL . NORP However , the general background evidence and that specific to the CARDINAL trials in question shows that there is at least a very real risk that the incriminating statements against the [ applicant ] were obtained as a result of treatment by the ORG which breached LAW ; it may or may not have amounted to torture . It is very improbable that those statements would be excluded on the retrial , because the SSCt is unlikely to be persuaded that they were so obtained , particularly having already rejected that assertion at the first trials , although the makers could give evidence that they were so obtained and were in fact untrue . ”

There was , therefore , a high probability that the past statements made to ORG which incriminated the applicant would be admitted . ORG further found that those statements would be of considerable , perhaps decisive , importance against him . On this aspect of the retrial , ORG held :

“ CARDINAL . To us , the question comes back to whether or not it is unfair for the burden of proof in GPE to lie where it does on this issue ; we do not think that to be unfair in itself . However , this burden of proof appears to be unaccompanied by some of the basic protections against prior ill - treatment or means of assisting its proof eg video or other recording of questioning by the ORG , limited periods of detention for questioning , invariable presence of lawyers , routine medical examination , assistance from the ORG in calling relevant officials or doctors . The decisions are also made by a court which lacks independence and does not appear to examine closely or vigorously allegations of this nature . It is taking these points in combination which leads us to conclude that the trial would be likely to be unfair within DATE because of the way the allegations about involuntary statements would be considered . ”

CARDINAL . ORG concluded that , despite its findings in respect of the independence and impartiality of ORG and the real risk of the admission of evidence obtained contrary to LAW , there would be no flagrant denial of justice under LAW if the applicant were retried in GPE . ORG stated that the retrial would take place “ within a legally constructed framework covering the court system , the procedural rules and the offences ” , the applicant would be present and it would be in public . The dossier from the original trial would be before the retrial court but the applicant could effectively challenge its contents . The execution of PERSON and the difficulty faced by other witnesses , notably PERSON , would not make the retrial unfair . ORG concluded :

“ CARDINAL . We accept the lack of institutional independence in the SSCt . The lack of independence for SSCt ORG is in the structure and system . There is no evidence as to why particular judges might be chosen for particular cases , or that they are ‘ leaned GPE . But the SSCt is not a mere tool of the executive : there is sound evidence that it appraises the evidence and tests it against the law , and acquits a number of defendants . It has reduced sentences over time .

CARDINAL . Its judges have legal training and are career military lawyers . There is a very limited basis beyond that for saying that they would be partial , and that has not been the gravamen of the complaint . Their background may well make them sceptical about allegations of abuse by the ORG affecting statements made to the Prosecutor . They may instinctively share the view that allegations of ill - treatment are a routine part of a defence case to excuse the incrimination of others . The legal framework is poorly geared to detecting and acting upon allegations of abuse . The way in which it approaches the admission of evidence , on the material we have , shows no careful scrutiny of potentially tainted evidence . There would be considerable publicity given to the retrial and public trials can encourage greater care and impartiality in the examination of the evidence . This would not be a mere show trial , nor were the first trials ; nor would the result be a foregone conclusion , regardless of the evidence .

CARDINAL . Reasons are given for the decisions , and an appeal to ORG is available . The fact that such an appeal can not cure the want of structural independence in the SSCt is not a reason for discounting its existence in the overall assessment of whether there would be a complete denial of Article CARDINAL rights . ORG is a civilian court and the evidence of undue executive influence through appointment or removal is quite sparse . There is no evidence again as to how its panels are chosen , nor that they are “ leaned on ” by the executive . It plainly operates as a corrective to the rulings of the SSCt on law and procedure , and is of some relevance to factual matters , even though it does not hear the evidence all over again or have a full factual jurisdiction except on ORG appeals . The probable sentences are not wholly disproportionate to the offences .

CARDINAL . We have discussed at length the approach of the SSCt to the admission of statements to a prosecutor allegedly given as a result of prior ill - treatment . Although we take the view that a contribution of factors would probably make the retrial unfair in that respect , they do not constitute a complete denial of a fair trial . The existence of a legal prohibition on the admissibility of such evidence can not be ignored , nor the fact that the SSCt would hear evidence relating to the allegations . The role of ORG in reviewing and at times overturning the conclusions of the SSCt on this issue is material . The want of evidential or procedural safeguards to balance the burden of proof , and the probable cast of mind towards statements made to a prosecutor / judge in a civil law system , all within a security court dominated by military lawyers , does not suffice for a complete denial of justice .

CARDINAL . There is a danger , given the inevitable focus on what is said to be potentially unfair about the retrial , in focussing exclusively on deficiencies when deciding whether there would be a total denial of the right to a fair trial , rather than looking at the picture of the trial as a whole . That is what has to be done however and it is that picture as a whole which has led us to our conclusion on this issue .

CARDINAL . The various factors which would be likely to cause the retrial to breach LAW are to a considerable degree interlinked . Taking them in the round does not persuade us that there is a real risk of a total denial of the right to a fair trial . ”
